subject: Productivity
title: The Yerkes-Dodson Law
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Yerkes-Dodson Law usable.

hook.text: Too little arousal and you're bored. Too much and you're panicking. Peak performance lives in the middle.

buildup.text: Robert Yerkes and John Dodson discovered in 1908 that performance follows an inverted-U curve with arousal.

discovery.text: Moderate stress and excitement produce the best results. This applies to sports, exams, and creative work.

twist.text: The curve shifts by task complexity. Simple tasks tolerate more arousal. Complex tasks need a calmer state.

climax.text: Peak performance isn't about eliminating stress. It's about finding the right amount for the task at hand.

punchline.text: Not too calm. Not too stressed. Just right.

quiz.question: What does the Yerkes-Dodson Law describe?
options: Performance peaks at moderate arousal and drops at extremes
Performance is unrelated to stress levels
